title: Why Ole Gunnar Solskjaer would be prepared to step down as Manchester United manager
text:
Ole Gunnar Solskjaer knows the pressure is building on his position (Picture: Getty)

Manchester United manager Ole Gunnar Solskjaer would consider his own future at Old Trafford if he felt he was damaging the club, sources have told Metro.co.uk.

The Norwegian is under increasing pressure ahead of Sunday’s Premier League clash against Liverpool and the Red Devils could find themselves in the relegation zone if results go against them over the weekend.

Solskjaer’s arrival injected positivity into a despondent United squad last December but results faded badly after the club appointed the 46-year-old on a permanent basis.

The nine points United have picked up from eight matches this term represents their worst start to a league campaign in 30 years and Solskjaer already appears to be playing down his side’s chances of finishing in the top four; a bare minimum requirement at the start of the season.

United have made their worst start to a league season in 30 years (Picture: Getty)

Ed Woodward, United’s executive vice-chairman, launched a defiant defence of Solskjaer on Thursday by insisting that the pair are working in tandem to revive the club’s fortunes after the malaise that set in following Sir Alex Ferguson’s retirement.

Advertisement

Advertisement

Anger from supporters is yet to turn towards Solskjaer and is unlikely to given his status at the club. Instead, the away support at AZ Alkmaar and West Ham directed their ire at Woodward and the Glazer family.

Woodward was instrumental in Solskjaer’s appointment and decided against waiting until the end of the 2018/19 campaign to hand him the job on a full-time basis, making the move in late March instead. After four managers in five years, Woodward can ill-afford to get another one wrong. Least of all when the man in question is a club legend.

That’s why the club remain behind Solskjaer. They do genuinely believe he has made positive, long-term decisions in the last six months that will benefit the side in years to come. They were impressed with his identification of transfer targets and believe he has helped transform that aspect of the club in a such a relatively short space of time.

But, while Woodward spoke about rebooting the club for the long-term, there is no escaping the present. Solskjaer has spoken about Sunday’s clash against Liverpool as being the ‘perfect’ chance for his squad to respond to recent setbacks but rarely – if ever – in the Premier League era have United entered into a game against their arch rivals as such underdogs.

The tide is yet to turn against Solskjaer and he retains favour with supporters, who in the main would rather watch a diminished side than dismiss a legend.

Advertisement

Advertisement

United’s board broadly share the same view but poor results can only be stomached for so long. Solskjaer’s side haven’t won away from home since March and they face four consecutive matches on the road after Sunday’s test against Liverpool.

Woodward is backing Solskjaer – but results need to improve (Picture: Getty)

It is hard to see a short-term fix to the club’s problems and Solskjaer is already looking for resolutions in the January transfer market. Club sources have spoken about simply ‘getting through to January’ before taking stock of the club’s position, so difficult has there start to the season been.

Solskjaer remains absolutely determined to turn things around but he’s under no illusions about the task he faces and recognises his status at the club can only buy him so much time. He maintains he can reverse recent results but sources have told Metro.co.uk that he has ‘too much respect’ for supporters to put his pride before the club’s best interests.

It’s why those close to Solskjaer believe he could jump before he’s pushed at Old Trafford and would genuinely consider stepping aside if he felt he was not the best man for the job.

Beyond that is Solskjaer’s acceptance that he was not the club’s first choice to replace Jose Mourinho last December. He was a caretaker, brought in to guide the club through the remainder of the season while they searched for a long-term successor.

Advertisement

Mauricio Pochettino has long been viewed as that man and it’s not inconceivable to think the Argentine could be available in the not-too-distant future if his troubles at Tottenham persist.

United stuck with Louis van Gaal against their better judgement in the winter of 2015 before sacking the Dutchman at the end of the season following an FA Cup final victory against Crystal Palace. Mourinho cast a shadow over the Dutchman’s final months at the club and it became an open secret that the Portuguese would take charge once the season had finished.

Solskjaer would not allow such a scenario to play out and would step aside if he no longer retained the full support of the board.

At this moment in time, the club remain fully behind Solskjaer and are desperate for him to succeed. The last thing they need is to be seen to be sticking the knife into an icon.

They hope it never comes to that.
